Dear Ms. Shell:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
1/3/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan
is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all of
the following information prior to employment or at the
time specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee
and which are less than 12 months old.
One of thirty-nine employee files did not have three written references as required.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during the licensing
period.
3

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
• Renewal evaluation dated 1/25/24, CAP approved 1/25/24. One violation
was found regarding employee records. Nine staff did not have timely
performance evaluations. The agency implemented the CAP successfully
and has not had any repeat violations.
• Special investigation 2024SIC0001560 completed on 9/25/24, CAP
approved 10/10/24. The agency had two violations: rule 158, due to staff
using humiliating language toward a youth and rule 109 due to staff using
their cell phone to make personal calls in front of youth. The agency CAP
was implemented and will continue to be monitored by DCWL through
April 2025. At this time, there are no repeat violations or additional
concerns in these areas.
• Special investigation 2025SIC0000024 completed on 11/26/24, CAP
approved 1/8/25. The agency had two violations: rule 159 due to staff
using a restraint technique that did not follow the approved procedures
and rule 112 for staff observing the improper restraint and not intervening
to correct it. The agency CAP is in the process of being implemented and
will continue to be monitored by DCWL through July 2025.
Financial Overview
The financial audit for 2024 has not been completed at this time. However, the
agency provided the 2023 audit and 2024/2025 budgets. No financial concerns
were identified.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator (CA) Assessment dated 1/3/25 was reviewed and
discussed. The CA reported the CAPs have been implemented regarding the 2024
renewal and two special investigations. The CAPs included additional training for
staff, counseling and termination of staff, the purchase of cell phone lockers, and
review of agency policy. The CA stated there were no barriers associated with
implementing the CAPs and it is anticipated compliance will be achieved. The
facility had one unplanned discharge during this review period. The discharge
occurred due to the youth being placed in an inpatient hospital setting that could
better address their mental health needs.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on-site. Both staff reported they enjoy their jobs, but
acknowledged it is difficult at times. Staff stated that the youth sometimes have
very challenging behaviors and seem disinterested in making progress on their
goals. Staff reported they continue to try to be positive role models and encourage
youth to make good choices that will lead to a successful future. Staff also reported
struggling with working multiple double shifts or mandated overtime. However, that
has improved recently with an influx of new employees. Staff stated their
4

supervisors are very knowledgeable and supportive. Staff did not identify any
needs at this time.
Three youth were interviewed on-site. Youth reported they feel safe with staff at the
facility and have someone they could talk to if there were problems. However,
some of their peer’s behavior makes them feel unsafe at times. Youth reported they
have adequate clothing and bedding. Two of the youth reported they do not like the
food at the facility and are not always given alternatives if the meal is something
they do not like or cannot have. This concern is currently being addressed in
special investigation 2025SIC0000226. No other concerns were reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The facility was observed to be clean and appropriately furnished. Medication was
properly stored in a locked cabinet, in a locked room. Youth had seasonally
appropriate bedding and access to clothing and hygiene items. However, the
overall condition of the building has declined in recent weeks due to destructive
behavior by three youth. The youth kicked holes in walls, broke windows, broke
doors, and peeled paint and trim from several locations. Maintenance continues to
make repairs but has had difficulty keeping up with the destruction by the youth.
The Chief Administrator reported they are in the process of purchasing windows
that are more shatter resistant, and an anti-ligature wall covering to prevent further
damage by youth. Progress on the repairs will be evaluated during the next
quarterly unannounced on-site visit.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
